title: DIY Like a Pro This Easter: 4 Smart Fixes for a Comfier, Warmer Home

content.value: The Easter long weekend is the perfect time to tackle those quick home improvement projects you’ve been putting off. Whether you’re battling a room that’s always too hot or too cold, or considering smart home options, here are four quick DIY ideas that can improve your home’s comfort, boost energy efficiency, and elevate your interior style.
1. Fix the Room That’s Always Too Hot or Too Cold

Every home has that room. A sun-drenched lounge that overheats in the afternoon or a chilly bedroom that never seems to warm up. The fix? Upgrade to thermal insulating blockout blinds or lined curtains. Not only do thermal window furnishings help regulate indoor temperatures, they can reduce your reliance on heating and cooling, in turn lowering your energy bills.
Pro tip: With winter closing in, now is the perfect time to DIY those thermal blinds and curtains, custom-fit to your windows and personal style.
2. Start your smart home journey

Considering smart home upgrades for your place? Start small. You can retrofit a battery-powered motor to existing roller blinds in high-traffic spots like the living room or bedroom. Add a 5-channel remote and expand to other rooms when you’re ready.

For a full solution, the WhisperTech Bundle is an all-in-one motorisation starter kit that includes a blind, motor, charger and remote for a fixed price. The ultimate in modern convenience, sleek design, a market-leading whisper-quiet motor and quick to install - it's a DIYer's dream.
Pro Tip: Motorised blinds are great for kids’ spaces—no cords or chains mean one less safety risk.
3. Refresh a Forgotten Space

Not every update needs to be front and centre. Show some love to a hallway, laundry, or spare room, especially if it's still rocking whatever the last owners left behind. A simple roller or Roman blind can change the vibe of those overlooked areas and add value to your place.
Pro tip: Neutral or textured fabrics keep things light and bright, especially in small or low-light spaces.
4. Use the Easter Break to Plan Ahead

Too many egg hunts to DIY this weekend? Long weekends are perfect for planning your next project. Order free fabric samples online now and have them ready to test out in your space. Experiment with lighting by folding the swatches and holding them to the window to see them in different lighting conditions. Feel the fabric of each sample to gauge its texture and thickness and hold it against your walls, furniture, and other samples to see how colours complement or contrast.
Pro tip: Don’t forget to check the back of the fabric. What it looks like from the outside can make a big difference to your home’s street appeal.

You don’t need to renovate your whole house to notice the difference. From a cord-free blind in the kids’ room, better-insulated rooms ahead of winter, or simply getting samples sorted for your next project, small changes can make your home feel brand new.
Plan Now, Save Later

Whether you’re mapping out ideas or ready to roll up your sleeves, a free consultation with a design expert can help you find the perfect fit for your space and budget. Get a quote during the DIYblinds Easter Sale, and we’ll honour your 15% discount across blinds, curtains, and shutters for 30 days—so you can plan now and lock in the savings when you’re ready.

title: 2025 Window Furnishing Trends: Insights from Zhana Garkinis - Fourteen Oh Five

content.value: As we look ahead to 2025, the world of window furnishings is evolving in exciting and innovative ways. With an increasing focus on technology as well as personal expression, it’s important to stay ahead of the curve on emerging trends. Here’s my perspective on what to expect in window treatments in the coming year.
Smart Blinds and Automated Solutions

Technology continues to transform home design, and window furnishings are no exception. Smart blinds that can be controlled from smartphone apps or voice assistants for example, are set to become even more popular in 2025. Imagine adjusting your blinds with just a tap or a voice command, allowing you to control light, privacy, and energy efficiency with ease. This trend combines convenience, functionality, and sustainability, making it a must-have for modern homes.
Embracing Earthy Colours

Colour trends in window treatments will lean heavily toward earthy tones in 2025. Rich greens, warm terracottas, and soft browns will dominate the palette, creating a serene, grounded atmosphere. These colours are wonderful options too, since they foster a sense of connection to nature and promote well-being. Expect to see these shades paired with linen-look sheers, offering a harmonious blend of elegance with a more laid back vibe.
Layering Textures for Depth

Layering will continue to be a key design technique in 2025, adding depth and visual interest to any room. Mixing different window treatments for example, such as pairing light sheer curtains with heavier drapes or blinds, can create both aesthetic appeal with practicality. This approach allows for enhanced light control and improved insulation, while still also offering opportunities for creative expression.
White Sheers for a Fresh, Airy Feel

I believe that white sheers will still remain a top choice in 2025, bringing a light, airy feel to any space in your home. They gently filter and diffuse natural light, while still offering a sense of privacy. Ideal for living rooms and bedrooms, white sheers can create a serene, elegant atmosphere that complements a wide range of design styles, and this is why they are still one of our most specified styles of window furnishing today.
Classic Shutters for Timeless Elegance

Shutters remain a classic choice in window treatments too, known for their enduring appeal and functionality and can adapt to various styles and aesthetics. They add architectural interest to a space, while providing excellent light control and insulation. Their sophisticated look complements both modern and traditional homes, making them a staple in our everyday design choices. They also pair beautifully with sheer curtains to achieve a more timeless design aesthetic.
The Return of Roman Shades

Roman shades are making a stylish comeback, offering a timeless elegance that complements both traditional and contemporary interiors. In 2025, expect to see them in a range of textures and patterns, adding versatility to suit any decor style. Roman shades are also known for their ability to softly filter light while maintaining privacy - making them ideal for creating a warm, inviting atmosphere in any room.
Final Thoughts

As we look toward 2025, the world of window furnishings is full of exciting possibilities. Whether you're drawn to smart technology, the classic elegance of Roman shades, earthy colour palettes, or the timeless charm of shutters, this year’s trends offer something for every style.

To explore more of our design work and insights, be sure to follow our journey on Instagram @fourteen.oh.five where you’ll find lots of inspiration on how you can incorporate window furnishings into your home, and keep an eye out as we’ll be soon be sharing all the spaces of our recently completed Keilor East Project, where we've expertly combined sheer curtains, shutters, and roller blinds, to create the perfect home atmosphere.

title: Preparing Your Home for Auction: Insights from The Block’s Nicole Jacobs

content.value: With the auctions on
The Block 2024

upon us, we spoke to Buyer’s Advocate Nicole Jacobs, a regular on the show and property expert, about preparing a home for sale. As Nicole shared, styling a home is more than just decor—it’s about creating an emotional connection with potential buyers that can directly influence the home’s perceived value.
Having helped clients successfully purchase 14
Block
properties over the last 20 years, Nicole brings invaluable insights on what makes a home stand out at auction. Here are her expert tips for making your home auction-ready and maximising value.
The importance of dressing your home for sale

When asked if styling is essential, Nicole says: “Absolutely. Unless you're an interior designer who’s already scoped it out, styling your home is crucial.” Preparing a home for sale involves creating a balanced, inviting space that helps potential buyers envision their lives there.

Nicole advises starting with decluttering but warns against making the space too sterile. “The goal is to have a home that feels like a home—warm, inviting, and ready for someone to imagine their life there.”
According to Nicole, well-executed styling not only captures attention but can also drive up bids. She recalls one memorable buyer who was so captivated by a
Block

property that she declared, “I’m not leaving until I’ve bought it.” This emotional connection, Nicole explains, is what inspires competitive bidding and leads to successful sales. “When buyers are emotionally invested, they see more value in the home and are often willing to pay a premium.”
Window furnishings: A small change with a big impact

Nicole points out that high-quality window furnishings are more than just decorative elements—they can significantly enhance a room's ambience and perceived value. “Window treatments are like the final stroke in a beautiful painting. They complete the room,” she shares. From soft sheers that add warmth during the day to blockouts for evening privacy, window furnishings allow homeowners to control light and create an inviting atmosphere. “For instance, in a modern home with concrete finishes, soft sheers can soften the look, while a Victorian property might benefit from shutters to retain that period style,” she adds. These finishing touches add a sense of refinement that makes a lasting impression on buyers.
Choosing base elements to create cohesion

Finding high-quality, cost-effective furnishing options can enhance value without breaking the bank. Nicole suggests that homeowners begin with a core design element like window furnishings, which can set the tone for the rest of the room. “When you choose a base element like
curtains

, the rest of the decor—sofa colours, rugs, and accents—can harmonise around it,” she explains. This creates a sense of cohesion that gives the room a polished, high-value look that appeals to buyers. This approach not only ties a room together but also adds an overall sense of quality to the home, making it feel well-curated.
Embrace modern trends: motorisation and smart home integration
Modern buyers are increasingly drawn to homes with smart features, and
motorised window furnishings

are no exception. “Imagine a buyer sitting on the couch, pressing a button, and watching the blinds close—it’s a real ‘wow’ moment,” Nicole says. Motorised blinds and curtains, particularly when combined with blockouts or sheers, add a touch of luxury and convenience. “Motorisation is more than a trend; it’s a feature that appeals to both tech-savvy and traditional buyers looking for ease and sophistication,” she explains. This can make a home feel higher-end which, in turn, boosts perceived value.
The benefits of pre-installed window furnishings for developers and new builds

Developers or house flippers sometimes skip window furnishings in new builds or renovation, assuming buyers want to make these choices themselves. However, Nicole believes pre-installed, high-quality window treatments can be a valuable selling point. “If the developers get it right, it saves buyers the hassle and creates a finished, move-in-ready look,” she notes.

This approach can create an immediate emotional connection, allowing buyers to picture themselves in the space without the additional expense or effort of installing curtains or blinds. Nicole adds, “Stylish window furnishings offer warmth and comfort, which can make the home feel more valuable from the moment buyers step in.”
Looking back on
The Block
: lessons from successful homes
Reflecting on her time on
The Block,

Nicole shares that the most successful contestants are those who consider the house as a cohesive whole, rather than as a collection of individual rooms. “Contestants like Ronnie and Georgia plan with a cohesive vision from day one, and that creates a flow buyers love,” she says.

It’s this whole-house approach that attracts potential buyers to auction day with excitement and competitive bids. “A beautifully styled home is what turns a house into someone’s dream home,” she concludes.

Nicole’s insights remind us that preparing a home for auction is an art and a strategic investment. With attention to detail in styling, window furnishings, and smart home features, you can create a lasting impression that appeals to buyers’ emotions—and ultimately, to their sense of value.

title: 6 Custom Curtain Solutions for Your Space

content.value: Custom curtains are more than just a style statement—they are the answer to many of your design dilemmas. Whether you’re looking to boost privacy, control light, or enhance the flow of your space, custom curtains can be tailored to meet your exact needs.
Let’s explore six ways custom curtains can solve common design challenges, with some standout inspiration from
The Block 2024
houses.
1. Create height and drama with floor-to-ceiling curtains

If your room feels small or lacks height, floor-to-ceiling curtains are a game-changer. By stretching the fabric from ceiling to floor, these curtains draw the eye upward, creating the illusion of taller ceilings and a more open space.
The teams on
The Block
nailed this look in their master bedrooms, with
House 1
House 2
, and
House 4
using recessed ceiling tracks. This detail created a seamless, sophisticated vibe that instantly made the rooms feel expansive.
2. Maximise light blockout with wider-than-frame curtains

Need better light control? Curtains that extend beyond the window frame are the perfect fix. By covering more of the wall, wider-than-frame curtains minimise light leakage, providing greater blockout—ideal for bedrooms or media rooms where darkness is key.

This approach doesn’t just solve a problem; it also enhances the aesthetics of your windows. This simple extension adds a sense of luxury and scale, making the windows appear larger and more dramatic.
3. Conquer tricky window shapes with custom raked curtains

Do you have angled windows and straight curtains that aren't working for you? Custom raked curtains are the solution you’ve been looking for. These curtains are made to fit the exact angle and shape of your window, providing a flawless, tailored look without compromising functionality.
House 5 on
The Block
used raked curtains as the hero feature in their winning main bedroom. The curtains highlighted the architectural angles, turning a challenging design element into a standout feature.
4. Choose the Right Drop Length for Your Style and Space
How your curtains meet the floor can dramatically change the look of your room. Here are three popular drop-length options to consider:
Just touching
: For a polished, modern look, the curtains skim the floor seen throughout
The Block
houses.
Puddled
: A designer favourite, this style has extra fabric pooling on the floor, adding softness and luxury—perfect for formal spaces like living rooms or bedrooms.
Off the floor
: Ideal for high-traffic areas or places where cleaning is a priority, curtains are hung slightly above the floor to prevent dust collection and dragging.
Whether you're after drama or practicality, selecting the right drop length ensures your curtains suit both your style and functional needs.
5. Customise curtain openings to fit your design

If you have large windows, sliding doors, or stacker doors, the placement of your curtain openings can make all the difference. Aligning your curtain openings with architectural features helps create a seamless flow between indoor and outdoor spaces.
House 1 on
The Block
showcased this perfectly, designing their living room curtains to open in sync with their stacker doors, creating a smooth transition to the outdoor area.
6. Make a statement with designer curtain rods

Curtain hardware doesn’t have to fade into the background—it can become a striking design feature. With custom curtain rods, you can choose sleek and modern colours, decorative finishes or custom lengths to elevate the entire room.
House 3 on
The Block
took advantage of this in their main living area, where a Designer 25 rod became a design statement of its own, adding both function and flair. In the
Block 2023
Steph and Gian
used black rods to tie their design elements together and create their cohesive Japandi aesthetic.
Let Custom Curtains Solve Your Design Challenges

From controlling light to handling tricky window shapes, custom curtains are the key to creating a space that’s as functional as it is beautiful. No matter the challenge, whether it’s achieving perfect privacy, maximising blockout, or adding a bold feature, custom curtains offer a tailored solution to suit your space.
Need help choosing the perfect curtain option for your home? Our
design consultants
are here to guide you through all the possibilities and help you find the ideal custom solution.

title: Using Curtains as Room Dividers: A Stylish and Cost-Effective Way to Create Extra Space

content.value: Ever feel like your home is just one open space where everything blends together —your living room, office, and maybe even a playroom for the kids? Or perhaps you’re desperate for some privacy when guests crash at your place for the holidays? If you're nodding your head, it's time to think about curtains—not just for your windows, but as room dividers. Curtains are the perfect solution when you need to reimagine your space, without the hassle (or cost) of building walls or doing major renovations. Plus, they’re renter-friendly!
We saw this clever trick on
during office and rumpus week.
House 3
used a gorgeous eucalyptus-coloured dimmout curtain to divide their rumpus from the games area, giving them a flexible space for entertainment and relaxation.
House 4

, on the other hand, took things up a notch with large-scale black Satori sheer curtains to section off their mezzanine, ensuring privacy while maintaining a sense of openness. While the judges weren’t entirely on board with the overall room design, their use of curtains was a brilliant example of dividing spaces without breaking the bank—or building walls.
Why Curtains are the Answer to Your Space Struggles
Whether you’ve got an open-plan living area that needs some defined zones or you’re just craving a little privacy, curtains are your best friend.

They offer versatility that permanent structures simply can't. Want to close off your space when guests are over but keep it open and breezy the rest of the time? Curtains can do that. Need a quiet corner to work from home but don’t want to invest in a big remodel? Yep, curtains have got you covered.

Plus, they’re super renter-friendly. You won’t have to worry about making permanent changes to your space. Curtain rods or tracks can be easily installed and removed, so you can easily switch things up.
Style Meets Functionality

Curtains aren’t just about creating makeshift walls—they bring a soft, cosy vibe to any room. Available in various colours, textures, and styles, they can add personality to your space while also solving practical problems. Want something light and airy to create subtle divisions? Go for
sheers
. Need more privacy for a workspace or a temporary guest room? Opt for heavier
lined
or
dimmout
curtains.
House 3's use of a curved rail to perfectly meet the wall shows how you can customise your design to fit the space you're working with.
House 4’s mezzanine design showed how curtains can work in more modern spaces. By using two large sheer curtains, they created a private zone without sacrificing the airy, open feel of their home.
Easy to Install and Adapt

If you're the DIY type—or just don’t want the hassle of hiring professionals—curtains are for you. You can mount curtain tracks or rods in no time, and they’re incredibly adaptable. They’re handy if you’re looking for a quick fix to turn one large room into two.

And if your home is starting to feel more like a storage space than a living space, curtains can conceal messy areas in lofts or large rooms. A simple curtain divider can instantly tidy up your home, giving it a clean, organised look—no expensive storage units or custom cabinetry required.
Picking the Perfect Curtain

So, how do you choose the right curtain for your space? Think about what you need. If it is privacy or sound reduction, go for thicker fabrics like velvet or lined options. Need something more lightweight to keep the space feeling open? Sheer fabrics are your go-to.
As we saw on
The Block

with House 3’s stylish dimmout curtain and House 4’s mezzanine makeover, curtains are more than just functional—they’re a design statement. And the best part? They’re budget-friendly, easy to install, and can instantly transform your space into something beautiful and practical.

title: The Art of Colour Matching on The Block: Window Furnishings, Paint Colours, and Soft Furnishings

content.value: Creating a cohesive and inviting space requires thoughtfully coordinating window furnishings, paint colours, and soft furnishings like pillows and upholstery. Whether you're aiming for a serene coastal vibe, minimalist style, or a bold statement, colour matching is essential to achieving a polished design.
In
The Block
Surf Club Challenge at Woolamai Beach, this was showcased with
Kumo Recycled

sheer curtains in Duckegg, perfectly matching the soft blue tones of the coastal setting. Motorised blockout blinds in One Block Gunmetal added functionality and a sleek aesthetic, ideal for the high-traffic club space.
As they do on
The Block
HomePro Design Consultants
can help you master colour matching and source the perfect fabrics for any space, ensuring your vision comes to life with both style and practicality.
Understanding Colour Theory
Colours are generally classified as:
Warm Colours
: Reds, oranges, and yellows—great for cosy, inviting spaces.
Cool Colours
: Blues, greens, and purples—ideal for calming, serene environments.
Neutral Colours
: Whites, greys, and beiges—versatile backdrops that adapt to various styles.
At Woolamai Beach SLSC, cool blues in the paint, sheers and blockout blinds create a calming coastal atmosphere.
Coordinating Window Furnishings and Paint Colours
Window furnishings often serve as focal points, and the right selection can enhance a room’s design.

In this challenge, the Duckegg sheers blended with the soft blues of the walls, creating a seamless connection to the coastal environment. Meanwhile, blockout blinds in Gunmetal were chosen to complement deeper tones, delivering a low-contrast, understated look that kept the design clean and elegant.
The tone-on-tone approach creates a sophisticated effect, while motorisation on every blind made adjusting light and privacy effortless, ideal for busy, highly used spaces.
Tying in Soft Furnishings
Soft furnishings like pillows, throws, and upholstery complete the look and feel of a space especially when they complement the window furnishings and paint, ensuring balance and cohesion.
Pick an Anchor Colour
: The coastal blue anchors the room’s colour palette and the soft furnishings in neutral shades like sand, seafoam, and soft greys add depth and texture while maintaining the theme.
Mix and Match Textures
: Incorporating natural fabrics like linen and cotton in the pillows bring warmth and comfort, enhancing the coastal vibe.
Pattern Play
: Subtle patterns in cushions and upholstery add visual interest to the space.
Final Tips
Test Swatches
: Always test paint and fabric samples
in the room to see how they look together and in different lighting conditions.
Functionality First
: Consider the room's purpose when selecting fabrics—durability and functionality are essential, especially for spaces that experience heavy use, like a surf club or living room.
Frame the View
: In rooms with stunning views, sheer curtains can help highlight the scenery without obstructing it.
The Surf Club Challenge on
The Block
2024 demonstrates how thoughtful colour matching can create a harmonious and functional space.
With
HomePro Design Consultants

, you can achieve the same level of cohesion in your space. Their expertise in colour matching and sourcing the right fabrics ensures every element—from window furnishings to soft furnishings—works together to create a space that reflects your style and meets your functional needs, just as it did on
The Block

title: Sustainable Style on The Block: Kumo Recycled

content.value: As sustainability becomes increasingly important in home design, our HomePro extended range offers innovative products like Kumo Recycled by James Dunlop.

The Eco-Friendly Journey: How Kumo Recycled is Made

Kumo Recycled transforms post-consumer plastic bottles into high-performance fabric. The process involves cleaning, shredding, and reconstituting PET bottles into polyester yarn through an advanced recycling method.
The result is a soft, durable fabric with a natural feel, ideal for residential and commercial use. Additionally, Kumo Recycled is
Oeko-Tex 100
certified, ensuring no harmful chemicals are used during production.

title: Moditerranean on The Block: Discover the Trend

content.value: A new trend has taken centre stage on
The Block
: Moditerranean. Showcased by
Courtney and Grant Freeman
in House Two, the style blends modern chic with earthy elegance and is set to become a fan favourite.
What is Moditerranean?

Moditerranean combines the raw beauty of natural landscapes with the sleek sophistication of contemporary design, combining old-world charm with modernism. It merges natural materials, curves, and organic shapes with polished finishes, creating warm, inviting, and timeless spaces.
The essence of Moditerranean lies in its celebration of indoor-outdoor living, where handcrafted details meet soft edges and a nature-inspired palette.

Courtney Freeman said: "Moditerranean is about bringing the tranquility and beauty of the outdoors into your home while maintaining a modern and stylish look. It's versatile, inviting, and perfect for creating a cosy yet elegant living space."
Key design elements of Moditerranean
Window furnishings

A key element in achieving the Moditerranean look is thoughtfully selected window furnishings. They enhance natural light, provide privacy, and add texture and warmth, contributing to the layered decor.

"Window furnishings play a key role in creating a Moditerranean home. Natural fibers in soft, neutral tones perfectly complement raw and refined elements in this trend, helping to create a cohesive and harmonious space," said Courtney.
HomePro by DIYblinds, window furnishings partner on
, helped realise Courtney's vision with a curated range of curtains and blinds that align with the Moditerranean trend, featuring:
Eco-friendly materials
like recycled fabrics that resonate with nature.
Warm, earthy tones
like green and beige blend seamlessly with rugged and polished surfaces.
Textural variety
through a mix of sheer and heavier fabrics to create depth and interest.
Natural materials

Incorporate natural materials like stone, wood, and clay to create a rugged yet refined aesthetic. Stone countertops, wooden beams, and clay pots add texture and warmth, contributing to the cultural fusion central to Moditerranean design.
Indoor plants

Indoor plants enhance the connection with nature, purify the air, and add vibrancy to your decor. Large potted plants, hanging planters, and succulents help blur the lines between indoor and outdoor living.
Statement lighting
Choose statement lighting fixtures made from natural materials like rattan, bamboo, or metal with a rustic finish. These fixtures serve as focal points, adding elegance and sophistication.
Why the trend is set to become a favourite
Moditerranean’s timeless, contemporary design, with its warm and inviting ambiance, resonates with style-conscious homeowners and fans of
The Block

Blending outdoor tranquility with modern style, the trend creates spaces that are both inviting and sophisticated. The seamless integration of old-world charm with modernism, detailed craftsmanship, and natural elements makes Moditerranean a trend that looks beautiful and feels like home.

title: 9 Living Room Curtain Ideas for a Cozy Retreat

content.value: Living room curtains serve a dual purpose, marrying functionality with visual appeal. They are essential for controlling light infiltration and securing one's privacy, yet they also play a critical role in the overall design of the space. While often overlooked or omitted, window treatments can significantly influence the ambience of a room. In the living room, often referred to as the hub of the home, the choice of curtains can contribute to the atmosphere by fostering a warm and inviting setting that reflects personal style.

Choosing the correct type of curtain for your living room can seem daunting amidst the myriad options. Several factors come into play, including the number of openings, the style of curtain tops and even the positioning of the curtain track.
This article shares insights into various living room curtain ideas, aiming to provide valuable guidance and creative inspiration for those planning to enhance their living spaces.
1. Ceiling Mounted Curtains for Living Spaces
Seachange by Hong Henwood Design, Graya, and Chris Clout Design
Ceiling-mounted curtains are a stylish and functional way to enhance your living space. Here are a few key benefits.
Height Illusion:
Fixing drapes at a ceiling level can elongate your room, creating the illusion of higher ceilings, making your space feel more open and grand.
Enhanced Privacy:
Ideal for covering French doors, ceiling-mounted curtains provide privacy when needed while allowing natural light to flow through when open.
Design Tip:
Choose dark patterns or textured fabrics rather than solid blackout drapes to avoid a stark appearance. Patterns add visual interest and soften the overall look of the room.
Perfect Fit:
We custom make our curtains to your specifications, meaning your curtain can finish how you want it to.
2. Elegant Sheer Curtains For a Luxurious Finish
Transformation by Farran
Elevate the sophistication of your living space with
sheer curtains
' timeless elegance. Here are a few key benefits.
Soft and Airy Ambiance:
Sheer curtains introduce a soft, airy ambience to any room, allowing natural light to filter through while maintaining a sense of privacy.
Refined Aesthetic:
The delicate fabric of sheer curtains adds a touch of refinement and elegance, creating a luxurious finish that enhances the overall decor of your home.
Versatile Styling:
Sheer curtains can be layered with heavier drapes or used alone for a minimalist look. Their versatility makes them suitable for various interior design styles, from contemporary to classic.
Enhanced Light and Privacy:
While allowing daylight to fill the room, sheer curtains provide privacy by obscuring the view from the outside. This balance is ideal for creating a bright yet secluded environment.
Elegant Movement:
The lightweight fabric of sheer curtains moves gracefully with the breeze, adding a dynamic and ethereal quality to your living space.
3. Channel Luxury Hotel Vibes With Double Curtains
Bring the opulence of luxury hotels into your home with the timeless elegance of
double curtains
. Here are a few key benefits.
Dramatic Effect:
Double curtains create a dramatic and sophisticated look reminiscent of the grandeur found in luxury hotels. The layering of fabrics adds depth and visual interest to your windows.
Sheer and Blockout Combination:

Choose a combination of sheer and blockout curtains from our range of premium yet affordable fabrics. Sheer curtains provide a soft, diffused light, while blockout curtains ensure complete privacy and light control.
Versatile Functionality:

This combination offers versatility in managing light and privacy. Use the sheer layer to enjoy natural daylight while maintaining the privacy and the blockout layer to darken the room for a restful ambience.
4. Japandi style encourages balance with natural, organic textures.
Japandi style

, a blend of Japanese and Scandinavian design, encourages balance with natural, organic textures. Using window furnishings, here are a few tips to transform a minimal Scandi space into a serene Japandi haven.
Layering for Depth
: Incorporate layers to transform a minimal Scandi space into a Japandi space. This can be easily achieved with window furnishings, which add depth and texture to the room.
Functional Roller Blinds
: Install roller blinds in the window recess for a practical solution to block out light and provide privacy. Their clean lines and simplicity align perfectly with the Japandi aesthetic.
Soft Sheer Curtains
: Layer roller blinds with sheer curtains to introduce softness and a gentle flow. Sheer curtains enhance the natural light while adding a delicate touch to the room.
5. Corner Windows Look Irresistible With Curved Curtains
Curved curtains
bring a sleek, sophisticated, and glamorous touch to corner windows. Here are a few key benefits
Versatile Design:
Choose between one or two bends, and have your curved tracks fit inside or wrap around your corners, tailoring the look to suit your space and style preferences.
Refined Appearance:
Sheer drapes offer a delicate and sophisticated appearance, adding elegance while allowing natural light to filter through.
Well-Lit Privacy:
These curtains maintain a well-lit yet private setting, balancing the need for natural light and privacy in your living space.
Inviting Ambiance:
Curved curtains are ideal for creating an inviting ambience in compact living spaces. They enhance the coziness and aesthetic appeal of corner windows, making the room more open and stylish.
6. Extend Period Windows With Box And Bay Curtains
Elongating period windows
can enhance their grandeur and the overall aesthetics of your room. Here are a few key benefits.
Curved Track with S-Fold Curtains:
Pairing a curved track with S-fold curtains adds a touch of elegance and sophistication to period windows, creating a smooth and graceful drape that complements the architectural details.
Wall Mount Placement:
Positioning the wall mount under picture rails or decorative vents maximises the height of your windows, making the room appear taller and more spacious.
Enhanced Grandeur:
This setup not only elongates the appearance of your period windows but also highlights their unique features, giving your living space a more distinguished and luxurious feel.
7. S-Fold Curtains For A Modern And Luxurious Finish
Transform your home with our
S-fold curtains
. The undulating folds of our fabrics allow for fluid elegance, which will beautifully frame the window when open and create a feel of modern sophistication when drawn closed.
Different curtain headings
S Fold
S-fold curtains form a structured S shape. The fabric drapes beautifully, creating clean vertical lines on the ceiling that give the illusion of height. This culminates in a modern, luxurious finish.
Double pinch pleat
This traditional heading is pinched in groups of two. It gives a classic look and is great in period homes.
Triple pinch pleat
This looks almost the same as a double pinch pleat, but the fabric is pinched in three groups to give a slightly more delicate look.
Pencil pleat

This neat, flat-stitched heading has folds similar to an S-fold curtain. The fabric is tightly gathered at the top, resembling a row of pencils. It works well on rear curtains when combined with S-fold curtains in front of them.
Knife pleat
This has a neat, flat-stitched heading. The fabric is gathered and pressed flat in uniform pleats. It’s an excellent finish for rear curtains when S-Fold curtains sit in front.
8. Combining Curtains with Blinds
Marzipan Residence - View Home Tour
Combining curtains with
blinds
offers a versatile solution for window coverings. Here are a few key benefits:
Privacy and Lighting:
This combination allows maximum control over privacy and lighting, enabling you to adjust to your preferences throughout the day.
Aesthetic Appeal:
Sheer curtains add a refined flair and soften the look of blinds, creating a sophisticated and cohesive design that enhances your room's overall aesthetic.
Versatility:
The dual-layer approach provides flexibility in managing light and privacy, making it suitable for various times and activities.
Harmony for Adjacent Windows:
Using uniform designs for curtains and blinds across adjacent windows ensures a harmonious and balanced look, contributing to a unified and stylish decor.
9. Thermal Curtains To Insulating Your Living Room with Style
Thermal curtains
, also known as double, lined, or blockout curtains, offer an effective solution for insulating your living room. Here are a few key benefits:
Temperature Control:
Thermal curtains help maintain a stable temperature in your room by preventing heat loss in winter and blocking heat in summer, ensuring a comfortable living environment year-round.
Energy Efficiency:
These curtains enhance your home's energy efficiency by improving insulation, reducing the need for heating and cooling systems, and lowering your power bills.
Eco-Friendly:
Using thermal curtains can help reduce your carbon footprint by minimising energy consumption, making them an environmentally friendly choice.
Cost-Effective:
They offer a budget-friendly alternative to expensive double-glazed windows while providing similar thermal benefits, making them a practical option for homeowners.

title: The Ultimate Guide to Window Furnishings for Every Room in Your Home

content.value: Window furnishing is crucial in interior design, blending functionality with aesthetic appeal. They control light, ensure privacy, and complete the overall look of your space.
In this guide, we'll explore various types of window treatments, including blinds, curtains, and shutters, and provide recommendations for selecting the right option for different areas of your home.
Window Furnishing Types
Blinds

Blinds are versatile and functional window coverings available in various options like roller blinds, double roller blinds, roman blinds, venetian blinds, panel glide blinds, linked roller blinds, vertical blinds, and outdoor zip blinds. Roller Blinds are a minimalist choice, suitable for living areas and offices. Double Roller and Roman Blinds offer elegance and light control, ideal for bedrooms and lounges. Venetian and Vertical Blinds provide adjustable privacy, perfect for offices and bathrooms. Panel Glide Blinds fit large windows and sliding doors, while Linked Roller Blinds ensure uniformity for adjacent windows.
Outdoor Zip Blinds
are designed for exterior spaces, providing durability and weather resistance.
Curtains

Curtains are fabric panels that offer a wide range of styles, patterns, and opacities. They add warmth and texture to a room and range from sheer to blockout offering varying degrees of light control and privacy. Curtains are ideal for living rooms, bedrooms, and dining areas where a touch of elegance and sophistication is desired.
Shutters

Shutters are solid window coverings with a classic and timeless look. They provide excellent insulation and durability, making them a long-term investment. Shutters are perfect for creating a traditional or rustic aesthetic and are suitable for all rooms, particularly those where privacy and light control are a priority.
In summary, each type of window treatment offers unique benefits.
Blinds:
Functional, easy to control, and suitable for practical spaces.
Curtains:
Warm, textured, suitable for creating a cosy ambience.
Shutters:
Classic, insulating, ideal for privacy and traditional styles.
Your choice will depend on the specific needs of your room, including light control, privacy, aesthetic preference, and overall design theme.
Selecting Suitable Window Treatments for Different Areas of Your Home
Choosing the right window treatments for different areas of your home can significantly enhance each space's functionality and aesthetic appeal.
For Living Rooms
The living room often requires a balance of privacy and natural light.
Recommendation:
Sheer Curtains
or
Roller Blinds
Sheer curtains allow for natural light while providing some daytime privacy. Soft fabrics will effortlessly diffuse natural light and add warmth and texture to the space.
Roller blinds can be made with blockout, light-filtering and sunscreen fabrics or in a combination of two, which means whatever you're hoping to achieve, we'll have you covered.
For Kitchens
Kitchens benefit from window treatments that are easy to clean and allow plenty of light.
Recommendation:
Visionwood Venetian blinds
or
PolyLux plantation shutters
Visionwood Venetian blinds and PolyLux plantation shutters are manufactured with durable materials that make them easy to clean and perfect for use in high-humidity areas.
For Bathrooms
Privacy and resistance to humidity are critical concerns in bathrooms.
Recommendation:
Visionwood Venetian blinds
or
PolyLux plantation shutters

Visionwood Venetian blinds and PolyLux plantation shutters are moisture resistant so that they won't warp or mould in high-humidity areas like bathrooms. They're easy to clean, too, so you don't need to sacrifice style with functionality.
For Bedrooms
Bedrooms require window treatments that provide privacy and control light for a good night’s sleep.
Recommendation:
Blockout curtains
or
Blockout roller blinds
to block light and
sheer curtains
or
light filtering blinds
to allow controlled light in. Blockout curtains can completely block out light, and blockout roller blinds offer excellent light control and insulating properties to help regulate room temperature.
For Dining Rooms
The dining room is a space for ambience and style, often needing a more formal window treatment.
Recommendation:
Sheer curtains
or
Roman blinds
Sheer curtains will add a touch of texture and elegance, while Roman blinds will add a traditional, elegant feel.
For Home Offices
In a home office, controlling glare on screens is critical while maintaining a bright, motivating environment.
Recommendation:
Plantation shutters
or
light-filtering blinds
. Shutters can add an elegant touch and allow for easy light adjustment while light-filtering blinds can reduce glare while keeping the room bright.
For Children’s Rooms
Safety and light control are vital considerations in children’s rooms.
Recommendation:
Cordless blinds or
motorised blinds
. Both options are safe for children and offer easy light and privacy control.
For Outdoor Areas (Patio/Balcony)
Outdoor spaces require durable, weather-resistant window treatments.
Recommendation:
Outdoor Zip Blinds
are designed to withstand elements and provide shade and privacy in outdoor settings
This guide serves as your roadmap to understanding and selecting the ideal treatments for each space in your home, ensuring they meet functional requirements and complement your style.

title: Guide to Energy-Efficient Blinds: How to Boost Insulation with the Right Window Coverings

content.value: Australia's diverse climate presents unique challenges for maintaining a comfortable home environment. Did you know that up to 40% of a home’s heating energy can be lost and up to 87% of its heat gained through windows? ( Source: yourhome.gov.au )
This blog aims to guide you through selecting the right blinds to boost insulation, thereby keeping your home warm in winter and cool in summer.
Types of Energy-Efficient Blinds
Honeycomb Blinds
Known for their unique design, honeycomb blinds create an air pocket that minimises heat transfer, making them an excellent option for both winter and summer.
Pros:
Excellent Insulation:
The unique honeycomb design creates an air pocket that minimises heat transfer, making them effective for both winter and summer.
Light Control:
They offer varying levels of light control, from sheer to blackout options.
Aesthetic Appeal:
Available in various colours and patterns, they can enhance the aesthetic appeal of any room.
Sound Absorption:
The cellular structure also provides some level of sound absorption, adding to their utility.
Cons:
Cost:
Generally more expensive than other types of blinds due to their specialised design.
Limited Style Options:
While they offer various colours, the cellular design might not suit all interior styles.
Cleaning:
The honeycomb structure can trap dust and allergens, making them slightly more challenging to clean.
Related :
How to measure for honeycomb blinds
How to install custom honeycomb blinds
Honeycomb blinds are currently not available to purchase online. It can be ordered via our
design consultants
Roller Blinds
Opting for blockout fabric in roller blinds can drastically reduce the amount of heat entering a room in summer and retain warmth in winter.
Pros:
Cost-Effective: Generally less expensive than other types of blinds, offering a budget-friendly option.
Versatility: Available in various fabrics, including blockout options that can drastically reduce heat and light.
Ease of Operation: Simple to operate, whether manual or motorised.
Minimalist Design: Their sleek and simple design can fit into almost any décor style.
Cons:
Limited Insulation: While blockout fabric can reduce heat, they may not offer the same level of insulation as honeycomb blinds.
Light Gaps: The design may allow small gaps where the fabric rolls, letting in slivers of light and potentially reducing energy efficiency.
Visionwood Venetian Blinds
Made from high-strength PVC, these blinds are effective in blocking heat transfer and offer flexible light control options.
Pros:
Durable: As they are made from high-strength PVC, these blinds are long-lasting and resistant to warping.
Heat Blocking: Effective in blocking heat transfer, making them good for energy efficiency.
Light Control: The horizontal slats offer flexible light control options, allowing you to adjust the amount of light entering the room.
Moisture Resistant: Being made of PVC, they are also resistant to moisture, making them suitable for humid areas like bathrooms.
Cons:
Aesthetic Limitations: The PVC material may not offer the same warm aesthetic as natural wood.
Weight: High-strength PVC can be heavier than other materials, potentially making them harder to raise or lower.
Cost: Quality Visionwood Venetian blinds can be on the pricier side compared to basic blind options.
Seasonal Benefits of Energy-Efficient Blinds
Winter
Materials like blockout fabric in roller blinds or the air pockets in honeycomb blinds can significantly reduce heat loss, helping to keep your home warm during the colder months.
Summer
Energy-efficient blinds can help maintain a cooler indoor environment by blocking out excessive heat and sunlight.
Factors to Consider When Choosing Blinds
Material
Different materials like fabric, wood, and PVC offer varying degrees of insulation. Choose the one that best suits your needs.
Operation
Consider manual vs. motorised blinds. Motorised blinds can be programmed to open or close based on the time of day, enhancing their energy-saving potential.
Installation
Proper installation is key. Ensure the blinds are installed close to the window frame to minimise gaps where heat can escape.
Consult a Window Furnishings Specialist
For personalised advice tailored to your specific design needs and location, consider consulting one of our
design specialists.

Investing in the right blinds is a simple yet effective way to boost your home's insulation and energy efficiency. With the right window coverings, you can make your home cooler in summer and warmer in winter, while also enhancing its aesthetic appeal.
Reference :
https://www.yourhome.gov.au/passive-design/glazing

title: How The Block learned about (and nailed) the Japandi trend

contentBlocks.title: The Block’s Steph and Gian embraced a pairing of interior trends in their beautiful, renovation styling.

content.value: When Steph and Gian were deciding on a style for their home on The Block it was a no-brainer. “The Japandi style makes for easy, liveable spaces that feel relaxed without being boring,” says Steph.

“While Scandi style is about pared-back functional minimalism, Japanese interiors like to embrace the beauty of life and all its imperfections. When you bring them together, you get a sophisticated look that relies on texture and earthy tones."
The Japandi trend leans on a seamless connection between indoors and outdoors.
“It’s important for people to engage with the outside space while they’re inside,” explains Steph. “We did this by framing our windows. The
S Fold Sheer curtains
we used in many of our rooms allow you to see outside at all times."
The team’s use of outdoor blinds is another way to increase the connection between the garden and the house. The
motorised blinds
come down from the top of the gazebo and can be used all year round.
“They block the sun and protect that space from the wind,” says Steph. “They’re perforated, so add some lovely texture too."
Other ways to increase the connection between indoors and outdoors include using organic plants.

“When it comes to plants and natural elements, nothing should feel forced,” says Steph. The bamboo on the kitchen counter is a perfect example of this. She adds: “You’d never include a case of styled roses in Japandi styling. It should look undone–and a little bit wild.
In a Scandi home, everything is neutral; beiges and whites form the base of the colour palette.
Japandi styling
relies on a stronger colour to tie it all together.
The base colours in Steph and Gian’s house are neutral, but they’ve used subtle black elements that link every room together.
“The black bar stools, lights, and bench in the bathroom all provide some grounding to the space,” says Steph.

The key to making this work is keeping the touches light so they don’t overpower the room. In their master bedroom, Steph and Gian included a DIY Blinds custom black curtain track to help bring the same theme to the space. “It’s subtle but works as a feature in itself,” says Steph.
Natural textures paired with smooth sleek surfaces are an essential part of making Japandi styling work well.

“Using different fabrics and layers helps bring some balance to the sleek lines that come from the traditional Scandi approach,” explains Steph. “Organic textures that give a nod to the outdoors work really well.

”The team discovered that small touches can be effective. From the jute runner in the bathroom to rattan storage baskets and paper light shades, the smooth materials associated with the Scandi style are softened.
Window furnishings go a long way to helping this too. The Linesque
Roman Blinds
in Raffia BO that sit on either side of the bed in the master bedroom have a great texture. The lines on them also work really nicely with the detailing on the bed.
”The team also used Linesque
Roman Blinds
in their bathroom, this time in the colour Hazel LF.

“These add a lovely, filtered light,” says Steph. “They’re made from a synthetic blend, so don’t go mouldy in the bathroom humidity, and are the perfect way to add a little extra softness to a tiled space.

contentBlocks.title: When Eliza and Liberty joined The Block, they had no renovation experience. A DIY Blinds’ Design Consultant stepped in to help.

in the recess so the doors were easy to use and the blinds could be moved quickly. Then she suggested adding
S Fold curtains
in a sheer fabric over the top to add some softness to the space,” says Liberty.
Windows that were hard to reach were also fitted with motorisation, this time for
Roman Blinds.
Motorisation

provides a seamless practicality to a space with tricky windows or doors, while also removing the need for chains, making them a safer option for pets and children. They can also be controlled remotely, offering a level of privacy and security even when you might not be home.
The Design Consultant helped with other tricky spaces in the house too, providing alternatives where the team needed them.

“Some of our windows wouldn’t work with certain blinds because of the overall look we wanted to achieve,” says Eliza. “Our consultant helped us find solutions. She also made us think about the length of our sheer curtains and talked us through the benefits of having them puddled or just touching the floor. There were so many decisions that we just weren’t aware of, it was great to have someone talking us through it all.

”When Eliza and Liberty mentioned a nook in the children’s bedroom, their consultant came up with a clever device using sheer curtains to make a cubby house.“She helped us progress the idea and made it work,” says Liberty. “She offered advice on how we should hang them the curtains and made sure they were lined up with the functional blinds on the windows.”

With more tricky decisions than they could have anticipated, the team looked to their DIY Blinds expert to help guide them in making sure the house felt well put together, rather than lots of separate spaces.
“We assumed we had to have the same window covering in every room, but our consultant explained it was ok to have different options,” says Eliza.
From style to functionality, Design Consultants are on hand to help with every decision you might need help with. For Eliza and Liberty this included what colours to use.

“She advised us that even though we had white walls, a creamy coloured blind would work well against them,” says Eliza. The team chose the Linesque fabric in a Raffia colour in their master bedroom and Hazel LF in the ensuite.
The sisters couldn’t be happier with their experience. “It stopped us feeling so overwhelmed,” says Eliza. “I’d recommend everyone uses a DIY Blinds Design Consultant.”

title: Double Act: The Block Meets DIY Blinds’ Blockout Blinds and Sheer Curtains

contentBlocks.title: Kristy and Brett used a clever combination of products to create a beautiful, functional look for their renovation.

content.value: “There are two large windows on either side of the bed, and another smaller one at the other end of the room,” says Kristy. “While that meant the light was amazing, it also meant there was no privacy. It was also hard to get a good night’s sleep because it was never properly dark."
To combat this, “
blockout blinds
were a no-brainer,” says Kristy. The pair chose the Kew Blinds in Natural across all three windows.
“They’re
motorised
, and all three blinds work off the same control, which means you can lie in bed and move any blind without getting up.”
Once the functionality of the space was organised Kristy and Brett were keen to add some texture to the room.
“We achieved this using
Sheer Curtains
on top of the blinds,” explains Brett. “It makes the room cosy and inviting, and when the blinds are pulled they let the light through.”
The couple chose the Mavi S Fold curtains in Opal. “We wanted something quite textured to contrast against the smooth Venetian plaster on the walls,” says Kristy.
Even when the blinds are open, the curtains can stay drawn. “They add a second dimension of privacy but still let light in, almost like a frosted window.”
Because the team didn’t want to drop the height of their ceiling, they opted for recessed
pelmets
on both sides of the room so they could avoid seeing the curtain track.
“The blinds sit within the pelmet too, so there’s a really seamless look,” says Kristy.
Kristy and Brett were concerned the pelmet might ‘box in’ the curtains, so DIY Blinds came up with a custom solution for the couple.

The curtain track, which is hidden in the pelmet, has a small, curved return at each end. This means that when you walk into the room, the curtain sits flush with the wall, rather than there being a gap between the curtain and the wall.

“It gives a beautiful, polished finish,” says Kristy. “The first thing you see is a soft drop of fabric instead of an unsightly gap. Small touches like that make such a difference to the finish of a room.”

On the side of the room where there are two windows, the couple opted to use one large sheer curtain instead of two smaller ones.“It’s functional, but we also used it as a styling piece,” explains Kristy. “It softens the plaster and gives you something to look at instead of a blank wall."
The curtain moves in one direction and is easily controlled with an acrylic wand–one of the options offered by DIY Blinds.
The team opted to have their sheers sit neatly on the ground rather than puddle on the floor.
“At this length, the curtains don’t bunch up on the fabric of the carpet,” explains Kristy. “They sit nicely and never look messy."
The clever use of two window furnishings, combined with the custom solutions designed by DIYBlinds, helped Kristy and Brett realise how curtains and blinds can be an integral part of a space.
“Window coverings shouldn’t be an ‘add-on’ to a room,” says Kristy. “They really are part of the whole space.”

title: Everything you need to know about using product combinations on your windows

contentBlocks.title: The Block’s Steph and Gian’s mix-and-match approach shows how window furnishings can define different rooms

content.value: “We wanted our master bedroom to feel spacious but cosy,” says Steph. “Because it’s so big, we needed to clearly define the different areas, so it didn’t feel too cavernous and empty.”
The couple achieved their vision by combining three different types of window coverings;
Roman Blinds
by the bed, then
Sheer Curtains
and
Roller Blinds
in the dressing area.
"Zoning different areas doesn’t have to be done with walls,” explains Steph. “Being clever with soft furnishings can be very effective.”

By the bed, Steph and Gian chose Roman Blinds. “Because they sit outside the window rather than in the recess, they make the window look a lot bigger,” says Steph. “Our windows are European style that tilt inwards, so the Roman Blinds work functionally here too; you can still open and close the window easily, without interfering with the drop of the fabric.”
In aesthetic terms, the colour and texture of the Roman Blinds go perfectly with the muted tones of the space.

“The cream colour really complements the dark brown bedhead,” says Gian. “We also loved the lines on the blinds–they work really nicely with the detailing on the bed and bring a sense of sophistication to the space. The texture ties in beautifully with our Japandi styling throughout the whole house.”
The sheer
S Fold curtains

in the living area signal that this part of the room has a different purpose.“They work as a piece of furniture in themselves,” says Steph. “There are two windows, but the curtains cover the wall in the middle as well. We used them to break up the harshness of the plaster wall and get rid of any awkward space in between the panes of glass.”
Steph and Gian chose one of DIY Blinds custom black curtain tracks to hang the sheers from.

“We wanted the track to be a feature in itself, rather than using a pelmet,” says Steph. “The black ties into other elements in the room, such as the lampshade and fireplace, to give it a really cohesive look.”
DIY Blinds offer different curtain lengths and Steph and Gian opted for a puddled finish.
“This look is perfect for a bedroom,” says Steph. “It feels a bit more undone and relaxed than curtains that simply graze the floor.”
While the aesthetics of sheers in a bedroom can bring a soft touch, it’s also important to consider privacy and darkness in a space where you sleep.
“We installed
Blockout Roller Blinds

in the reveal behind the sheers,” says Steph. “We used a plaster colour, so they blend in well with the walls. In the day they’re pulled up and you can’t see them at all. At night, they can be pulled right down so light doesn’t penetrate the room.”
They are also
motorised
for ease. “You can control the blinds when you’re lying in bed,” says Gian.“If you wake up in the morning and want to see some sunshine, all you need to do is press a button."
The pair couldn’t be happier with the results in the space.
“I think we’ve shown that the soft lines in window furnishings can be really powerful,” says Steph. “When you think of curtains and blinds as furniture, it can change the way you use them.”

title: How to choose the right blinds for your home

content.value: Choosing the right blinds for your home can turn a simple room into a beautiful space. Not only do blinds have functional benefits such as providing privacy, light control, and insulation, they also add warmth, texture, and atmosphere.
Not sure if you need Roller or Roman Blinds? Discover everything you need to know about choosing the right blinds for your home.
Book an online design consultation
right blinds for your home
Why should I have blinds in my home?
Insulation and reduced energy costs

. Glass window panes allow heat and light to easily enter or escape a room, making it difficult to maintain the required temperature. When blinds cover a window, they act as insulation, helping to keep a room cool in summer and warm in winter, and helping you save on energy bills.
Privacy

. Blinds are an easy way to provide privacy. Light filtering blinds provide daytime privacy whereas blockout blinds provide total privacy, day or night. Sunscreen Blinds let you see out, but don’t let passers by see in, so you can enjoy a view while maintaining your privacy.
Light control

. Sun glare through a window can make it difficult to see a TV or computer screen. Light filtering blinds diffuse the harsher rays and give your room a soft glow. They can also protect your furniture from being damaged through prolonged sun exposure.
Affordability

. Blinds are a cost-effective way of adding insulation, privacy and light control to a room. At DIY Blinds we have a wide range of options to suit your budget. All your orders are custom-made in Australia and delivered to your door, saving you time and money.
Ease of use
. Blinds are easy to control. Either choose a manual chain or
motorise
your blinds so they can be controlled automatically by a remote or voice activation, even when you’re not at home.
Style
. Whatever the style of your home, there’s a blind to complement it. Whether you want minimalist
Roller Blinds
, an elegant
Roman Blind
or a clever
Panel Glide Blind
, there’s an option for you. You can customise blinds in your home so you have matching fabrics across different products for a cohesive look.
Which are the best blinds for privacy?
Blockout blinds
These window coverings provide complete privacy. They’re also great at creating a dark environment during the day in a nursery or media room.
Sunscreen Blinds

These allow you to see out but don’t let passers by see in. They also block 95% of UV rays so lower the chance of fading in furniture fabric and are ideal for reducing heat and glare while still letting in some light.
Light filtering Blinds
These blinds offer daytime privacy while still letting light in, and are ideal for hiding unsightly views such as walls or fences. They work well in living areas.
What’s the difference between a recess-fit and a face-fit blind?
A
recess-fitted blind

sits inside the window frame. Depending on the thickness of the window frame around the glass, it may let some light in. Because they’re tucked out of the way, they offer a clean aesthetic and can help maximise space in small rooms.
Face-fitted blinds

sit outside the window frame. This allows the window to be completely covered by the blind and means the blind offers extra privacy and helps prevent light entering a room. It can also make your windows appear larger.
The DIY Blinds Way
If you’re not confident doing it yourself, DIY Blinds can help you
design, measure and install your blinds
so you get the right style for your home that fits exactly how you want it to.
How do I choose the right blinds for my home?
Here’s what to think about when you’re deciding which blinds are right for your home.
Colour
Subtle tones
such as pale grey, beige or warm whites are understated and won’t overpower the room. Darker tones make a statement and will draw your eye to the window.
See a beautiful example here.
Fabric

Different fabrics allow varying amounts of light to filter through, giving you a range of privacy levels. Sleek fabrics keep things streamlined and minimal, while chunkier, coarser fabrics can bring warmth and texture to a space.
Style

The style of the blinds you choose for your home will depend on how you need them to perform, and the aesthetic you like. Learn more about the different style of blinds and how to motorise your blinds here.
T
he DIY Blinds Way

All our blinds are custom-made and we offer more than 300 fabric and colour combinations to choose from. DIY Blinds is excited to announce our exclusive blind fabrics and colours range, launching in 2023. Watch this space.
How do I install blinds?
For blinds to be effective they need to be fitted, measured and installed correctly. DIY Blinds custom make your blinds so you get the perfect look. Follow our
step-by-step guides
to
measuring
and
installing
your own blinds.

title: Light filtering blinds: a guide for your home

content.value: If you love the idea of basking in a room bathed in soft light, rather than drawing curtains against the harsh glare of the sun, light filtering blinds are for you. Also known as translucent blinds, these window coverings allow natural light into your space while gently diffusing it. They also provide daytime privacy while still letting light in.
Discover the right
light filtering blinds
for you
How do light filtering blinds work?

Light filtering blinds are made from sheer or coarsely woven materials that allow a certain amount of light to filter through. This gives a soft, translucent look that can add texture or patterns to a room. Because of the material used, they also provide daytime privacy. Think of them as similar to a privacy film on bathroom windows; people looking in won’t have full visibility, and if you’re looking out, objects will be seen as silhouettes.
Why should I use
light filtering blinds?
Reduce UV damage.
Bright sunlight can cause damage to flooring and furniture, and cause artwork and books to yellow or become warped. Light filtering blinds reduce this exposure, helping protect your belongings.
Reduce energy costs.
Rooms in full sunlight heat up your home quickly, increasing energy costs when it comes to cooling. Light filtering blinds can reduce the glare from the sun.
Better, clearer screen viewing.
Glare from the sun can make it difficult to see computer or television screens. Light filtering blinds can improve screen visibility.
Screening without darkness.
They help hide or cover unsightly views such as fences or brick walls.
Are
light filtering blinds
the same as blockout blinds?

Blockout blinds provide complete privacy and make the room dark. They’re great at night or for creating a dark environment during the day. Light filtering blinds still allow light into the room, and are often used to cut the glare of the sun during the day.
Alternatives to light filtering blinds
At DIY Blinds, there’s another option, too. We offer a
Sunscreen Blind

, which provides increased daytime privacy without losing light. It blocks 95% of UV rays to limit fading, and is an ideal window covering for reducing heat and glare while still letting in some light.
The DIY Blinds Way
Because we’re
Australian Owned and Made
, we understand why light filtering blinds are important. We can help you
design, measure and install your blinds
so you get the result you want.
How do I choose
a light filtering blind?
Here’s what to think about when you’re choosing the right blinds or window coverings for privacy in your home.
Fabric
Different fabrics allow for varying amounts of light to filter through, and offer a range of privacy levels. We have sleek fabrics such as
Sanctuary
(light filtering), for people who like to keep things minimal; while our
Balmora (light filtering)
fabric is slightly chunkier, with a horizontal, linear texture that adds dimension to your windows.
Colour

Make the most of natural light filtering through with lighter colours such as white, pale grey and beige. Shades of charcoal, black, and earthy tones darken the room slightly, making them particularly suitable for media rooms. Understated tones look great on large windows without overpowering the room. Our light filtering blinds come in a range of
six fabrics, and 58 colours
, so you can choose the perfect one for your home.
The DIY Blinds Way
All of our light filtering blinds have a
4-star daytime privacy rating, and a 3 star nighttime privacy rating.
How should I install light filtering blinds?

For blinds to be effective, they need to be fitted, measured and installed correctly. Learn more here about the difference between recess and face-fit blinds and how to install to get the look you want. At DIY Blinds we give you all the guides and expertise to do it yourself at home. design, measure and install your curtains
. You can also book a
free online design consultation
for personalised advice.

title: Motorised blinds and curtains: Smart products for your home

content.value: Choosing motorised blinds and curtains for your home achieves several key goals for your overall look, feel and experience.

With exciting new technology giving homeowners more options than ever, issues such as security, privacy, insulation and energy efficiency are no longer a problem. Plus, motorised blinds and curtains look great.
Book an online design consultation
motorised options for your blinds
and curtains
The DIY Blinds Way

We partner with Somfy, the leading provider of motorised systems for window coverings. Connecting homes in a way that suits the unique needs of the DIY Blinds customer, Somfy systems are quiet and reliable, giving you full control with maximum style. Our partnership with Somfy allows us to offer you the best market rates for the highest-quality products. Read more about the cost of motorising blinds here.
Why should I choose
motorised blinds and curtains
Deciding to retrofit a motor to your existing roller blinds, or installing new
blinds and curtains equipped with motorisation,
has some significant benefits. Read more here about retrofitting motorisation to your existing blinds.
Control
- Many of our motorised systems can be accessed even when you’re not in the room, or even at home. This gives you ultimate control over the light, temperature and ambience of your home at all times.
Security and privacy
- On holiday or late at the office? Increase your security by activating your blinds and curtains to open and close at set times.
Comfort
- Sunlight glare spoiling your Sunday afternoon movie, or just too comfy to move? Activate your motorised blinds and curtains to open and close without having to move a muscle.
Safety

- Traditional chains and wands to control window coverings are still an excellent option for many households. But motorised blinds and curtains in a home with young children and pets could offer that extra layer of safety you’re looking for.
Functionality
- Control out-of-reach blinds for high or large windows with ease. Also perfect for those with accessibility requirements.
Cost

- Being able to activate your blinds and curtains to open and close when the temperature changes means you’re better able to keep rooms cool in summer and warm in winter. This helps keep the energy bills down.
The DIY Blinds Way
All of our products are Australian Made so we understand your climate and home life. We offer customised products that can be tailored to suit your unique space and lifestyle.
Book an online appointment
with one of our Design Consultants today.
How can I motorise my blinds and curtains?
There are several options when it comes to how you motorise your window coverings. Your style of home and your lifestyle needs will help you decide what’s right for you.
Remote only
- Motorised
Roller Blinds

and curtains don’t need a home automation system to work. Somfy has a range of 200m within a line of sight, and can also work through plaster walls in the home, Somfy’s technology will allow you to operate your remote control roller blinds and curtains with no internet or wi-fi connection.
Wi-fi Hub

- DIY Blinds offers two wi-fi hubs that when purchased with your window coverings will allow you to control your blinds and curtains remotely. Wi-fi blinds also allow for voice activation and means you can schedule set times for your blinds and curtains to open and close. The two options are:
Bond Bridge - works with Alexa or Google Home and SmartThings to control motorised products such as blinds, curtains, ceiling fans and fireplaces, all via the same mobile app.
Somfy Connexoon - works with Alexa or Google Home. The Somfy motors use the app to control your motorised curtains and blinds remotely via the internet or on a set schedule.

title: Bay window blinds and curtains: Expert ideas for your home

content.value: Bay windows can be the hero of a room – elegant and stylish, they bring in light and make a statement. However, choosing window coverings for a bay or box window can be tricky; get it wrong and they can look cluttered. But get it right and they can elevate a room even further, giving a high-end, bespoke feel.
Book an online design consultation
best blinds and curtains for your
bay windows
Curved curtains
Curved curtains

– curtains that are hung on curved tracks – are the ultimate way to highlight the elegance of a bay, box or corner window. They’re also the ideal solution for covering obstructions that project out of your window such as bulky handles or frames.

Choose curved curtains with an S Fold finish to elongate period windows and highlight soft, structured folds. Ceiling-mounted curtains add drama and make your room feel more spacious and your windows appear larger. To make the most of period features in a room, opt for wall mount-placed curtains slightly under the height of traditional picture rails.
The DIY Blinds Way
At DIY Blinds, our sleek curved tracks are made to fit perfectly into 90-or 45-degree corners; we also offer bespoke curtains if the shape of your window is different. You can
speak to one of our Design Consultants

for a bespoke custom offline solution. You can choose to have your curved tracks fit inside or wrap around your corners. Plus, we make curtains up to 8 metres wide with a 4.2 metre drop, so they fit the biggest of windows.
Corner tracks

Having tracks meet each other in the corner of a window looks great, and they’re quick and easy to install. This configuration allows you to open your curtains from the corner. When you measure correctly and the tracks join perfectly, they look as though they're on one single track.
DIY Blinds recommends

Choose how you split your curtains around a bay window to suit both your window and your room. A centre split gives a more traditional look, while having your curtains at either side of your box or bay window can give a more modern feel.
Plantation Shutters

Plantation Shutters can provide the perfect solution for box, bay or corner windows. They allow total light control while still allowing a connection to the outside. DIY Blinds offers a range of panel layouts to exactly match your space, making the shutters functional as well giving a bespoke designer look.

title: Plantation Shutters: Pros and cons

content.value: Plantation Shutters bring a high-end look to a space, as well as being versatile and functional.
These solid window furnishings are made from panels with rotating louvres that allow you to control light and privacy while also letting in natural light.
Discover some of the benefits of Plantation Shutters, as well as some examples of when they might not be suitable for your home:
Book an online design consultation to get ideas on some of the pros and cons of Plantation Shutters in your home
The DIY Blinds Way

Our PolyLux® Plantation Shutters are 100% custom-made in Australia. They’re durable, washable, VOC Free, and pet and child friendly. They won’t bleach or blister when exposed to intense UV rays and are aesthetically beautiful. This quality is reflected by a 20-year warranty.
Light control
Pros of Plantation Shutters

Plantation Shutters can help you maximise light in a room, especially if you have small, narrow windows. Our Plantation Shutters can be attached to frameless windows, which minimises the amount of shutter required and lets in as much light as possible. The louvres on the shutters can be rotated 180° in either direction,allowing you to control light and privacy; they can also be angled to let in natural light and views.
Cons of Plantation Shutters
Plantation Shutters won’t provide you with total darkness; this is best done by
Blockout Curtains
. If you like the look of Plantation Shutters but need total darkness in a room, pairing your shutters with curtains provides the best of both worlds.
Privacy control
Pros of Plantation Shutters:
Plantation Shutters are made up of rotating louvres that, when closed, offer complete privacy.
Cons of Plantation Shutters:
When closed, Plantation Shutters also block out light and views, in and out. If you’re looking for privacy but still want to be able to see outside, our
sunscreen blinds

provide increased daytime privacy, while still allowing you to see out, without losing light. They also block 95% of UV rays and are ideal for reducing heat and glare while still letting in some light.
Thermal insulation
Pros of Plantation Shutters
: Any window covering offers some sort of thermal protection. Both
face-fit
shutters and
recess-fit
shutters minimise gaps around the window and help with insulation.
Cons of Plantation Shutters
: If you need higher thermal insulation but like the look of Plantation Shutters, pair them with our
lined curtains
. Not only do these add insulation to a space, they also block light when drawn and reduce the intrusion of outside noise.
Style
Pros of Plantation Shutters:
Plantation Shutters can be used to highlight the traditional feel of a room or give it a sleek, contemporary look.
Face-fit
shutters generally bring a classic look to a space, while
recess-fit
shutters sit inside the window frame, giving a sleek and seamless effect.
Cons of Plantation Shutters:

While Plantation Shutters add impact and style to a space, some people like a softer look , particularly in their living areas and bedrooms. To enjoy the benefits of both, pair your Plantation Shutters with curtains. As well as helping to frame a window, curtains add some texture to a space.
Sheer curtains
diffuse sunlight and add texture to a room, while
lined curtains
bring a cosy, upmarket feel with their soft fabric folds. They also add extra insulation to the space.
Blockout curtains
provide additional thermal insulation and total darkness.
The DIY Blinds Way

All DIY Blinds PolyLux® shutters have a 20-year warranty, so you can be sure that you’re buying a high-quality product. They’re Australian Made, and come with just a seven work-day lead time, compared to most imported shutters which have an eight to ten week lead time. Our price beat guarantee means you get quality Australian Made shutters for the lowest price.
